body:
I see - good points!

The thing is, the steps to install a dev version are in a sense "simpler" than setting oneself up for contribution.

So, there are indeed two workflows:

* just installing the dev version
* setting oneself up for contribution, which includes installing an editable dev version

And I see how the two are inconsistent, since it's not clear for instance that you have to follow a slightly different sequence of git commands, but *still* ensure that you satisfy the build requirements.

Reworking the developer guide is high up on our priority list for docs - contributions in the area are also much appreciated. Let us know if you are up for that. We'll have a doc sprint w/c Aug 23.
There's an additional workflow: building a release version from source when no pre-built wheel is available for your operating system.

issue.title: [DOC] Update Documentation Content

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
#### Describe the issue linked to the documentation

There are several sections of the documentation that can be updated, integrated or otherwise changed. Running list below. 

The goal of this Issue is to keep track of the potential changes. 

- [X] Add initial glossary
- [x] Improve estimator overview
- [ ] Get Started examples for other learning tasks
- [ ] Improve Related Software (soft dependency table at the top, add column for "learning task"/"focus area"/"Category", see #1183)
- [ ] Add missing modules to API References (e.g. clustering)
- [X] Add thumbnails for Get Involved page (see e.g. https://pandas.pydata.org/docs/) and other pages with a relatively small number of items in table of contents
- [x] Add more info to Enhancement Proposals page (ideally reusing README from the repo)
- [x] Add table for core devs, CC members, CoC members and interns/mentees to Contributor page
- [x] Add reviewer guide 
- [X] Add events page with embedded Google calendar or link to it
- [x] Add page for community contributions/links for blogs posts, applications, etc.
- [x] Convert markdown files in about folder to .rst

issue.title: [DOC] clean developer set-up instructions and installation instructions - the two current sets of installations instructions are confusing

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
I've now seen multiple instances how the two sets of installation instructions create confusion:

* the short instructions in https://www.sktime.org/en/latest/get_involved/contributing.html
* the detail instructions in https://www.sktime.org/en/latest/installation.html

I think this needs to be resolved, e.g., that following the short instructions likely results in problems since build requirements need to be satisfied, the instructions being incomplete.

Concretely, here's what I propose to do:

* remove any `pip install` commands from the short instructions on the "contributing" page
* create a separate "developer set-up" page, which refers to the "install sktime from source" page. The "developer set-up" page is referred to from the "contributions" page. At the end there should be only two installation instructions - one for developers, one for the development version of sktime. It should be clear which is which, both should be comprehensive when followed from start to end, and none should have parts on the "contributing" page.
* stuff like precommits and testing setup should move to the "developer set-up" page

issue.title: [DOC] documentation & developer instructions (Windows experience) fixing umbrella issue

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
I've been trying to set up a sktime developer environment in my day job role, we have a standard hardware set-up that uses Windows laptops.
Unlike the unix/mac experience which seems smooth, I truly must say that the Windows experience of the developer instructions is quite a bit atrocious, even mere installation can be confusing.
We've done user testing with 5 people, and no one managed to complete the `sktime` developer set-up without any hassle.

So, we've decided to help by fixing this, with @eenticott-shell, @amrith-shell, by:

- [x] updating and validating the installation instructions in windows. Related issue: #1372, #1203
- [x] completing and re-organizing the developer guide (currently mostly empty!) and the "how to contribute" page. Related issue: #1448, #1203

issue.title: Windows installation guide for sktime development with Anaconda and PyCharm

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
A walk-through guide for setting up sktime for development with PyCharm and Anaconda. Also includes examples with pytest and pre-commit within PyCharm


#### Reference Issues/PRs
Contributes to part 2 of #1635 


#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
Documented example of installing sktime on Windows, specifically using PyCharm and Anaconda with extensive screenshots to guide new users. While PyCharm is used as the IDE, instructions are separated out so that just the environment instructions can be followed (i.e. Section 2) without need for PyCharm, if preferred.  

The notebook is in examples/windows_installation.ipynb and the other files that have been added are screenshots that are used within the notebook. 

#### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one?

No

#### What should a reviewer concentrate their feedback on?

No code introduced has been introduced but I'm not sure if this is the correct place for it - it may be better in the \docs but I'm not sure how best to include the images and have used a notebook as a first pass. Also, please comment on whether the instructions are informative or if you have suggestions for any changes

#### Any other comments?

body: I think this is addressed in #1707.
